Christopher Columbus.Action: Beguiles the Queen and court with hopes and promises about the New World expedition.
Presides over a state of chaos, degradation, and madness in the colony after settlement.
Appointed his brothers to important positions, injuring pride and dignity of nobles.
Promised to build a city, but built only a collection of huts in the wrong place.
Commanded each Indian to pay annual tribute and barbarously punished those unable to pay.
Forced nobles to undergo physical labor equally with Indians, reducing all to slavery.
Executed nobleman Adrian de Moxica who protested against such treatment.
Appoints his brothers to important positions, alienating the nobles who accompanied him.
Promises to build a city named City of Isabel but only constructs fragile huts in a poor location prone to destruction.
Fails to find easy gold as promised and forces indigenous people to pay tribute, leading to harsh punishments and unrest.
Subjects nobles to forced physical labor and reduces them to slavery, causing internal dissent and execution of protesting noblemen.
Loses control over the colony, resulting in chaos, degradation, and rebellion.
Encourages soldiers to marry native women.
Promises a paradise but creates a hell with horrors.
Does not swat insects crawling over his face when delirious, showing vulnerability and passivity.
Protects documents from rain despite devastated surroundings.
Encourages soldiers to marry native women and promises a paradise but instead creates a hell filled with horrors.
Is delirious, physically debilitated, and makes no effort to protect himself or his important documents from damage.
Despite adversity, he stands up and attempts to protect documents from water damage, showing a basic sense of responsibility.
Hums a song while walking with his son; watches his son's playful antics with amusement and calls him affectionately, lifting him onto the mule.
Expresses excitement and disbelief upon receiving the letter from Marchena, showing openness and engagement.
Engages earnestly in discussion about his plans and dreams with Marchena, indicating sincerity and trust.
Responds to Marchena's interruption about Esdras being a Jew with 'So was Christ!'
Mocks Marchena with 'I'll try to remember that, Marchena...' when advised not to let passion overwhelm him
Lifts Fernando onto the mule, showing care for his companions
Invites his son Diego to come stay with them, offering to do whatever makes him happy, and gently touches his shoulder.
Takes his son Fernando by the hand and drags him away from the execution scene to protect him from trauma.
Tousles his son's hair affectionately upon entering the house.
Explains to Beatrix his son's subdued behavior, showing awareness and communication about Fernando's feelings.
Notices his son's distress and removes him from witnessing the execution, showing awareness and protective behavior.
Calmly explains the reason for the son's subdued mood to the mother, demonstrating clear communication and emotional intelligence.
Mentions that 'They've agreed to see me in a week.' indicating he has arranged a meeting, reflecting planning and forward thinking.
Kisses Beatrix and shares an intimate, loving moment despite upcoming long absence.
Pours wine into Fernando’s water to distract and lighten his mood, smiling warmly.
Winks at Fernando and compliments Beatrix, creating a moment of shared affection.
Responds respectfully and knowledgeably to skeptical questioning from church dignitaries.
Engages calmly and sincerely in intellectual debate despite opposition.
Confidently presents his plan to sail west to Asia, showing knowledge of geography and previous scholars.
Faces skeptical experts questioning his calculations about Earth's circumference.
Listens to concerns about the crew’s survival, acknowledges the risk by saying 'Excellency, you are right.'
Presses his theories despite a murmur of protest and amusement, insisting on his viewpoint
Acknowledges limits of his knowledge and respectfully questions experts.
Demonstrates passion and willingness to risk his life, appealing sincerely to others.
Focuses on exploration and bringing new peoples to the word of God, showing idealistic intentions.
Seems somewhat dismissive of others' concerns about risk to their lives, but still asks if they agree to follow him.
Admits he is not a scholar but has studied extensively and recognizes unresolved questions among experts.
Acknowledges the uncertainty and risk involved, proposes a practical way to resolve theoretical dispute by making the voyage.
Appeals confidently and passionately to the assembly to back his plan despite opposition and risk.
Demonstrates awareness of both economic and religious motivations, indicating strategic thinking.
Responds calmly and unflinchingly to threats and accusations of heresy; maintains quiet confidence in his beliefs.
Uses religious references to assert a sense of divine purpose, possibly implying self-importance.
Calmly asserts his conviction that Asia can be found to the west and confidently challenges orthodox beliefs.
Meets the monk's threatening and challenging gaze unflinchingly, showing self-assurance.
Looks appalled and devastated when the commission rejects his proposal; expresses frustration that they didn't want to listen.
Reacts with devastation and despair upon reading the Commission's letter rejecting his plans.
Persists in his belief despite rejection, showing some confidence in his vision.
Damn God and others, lashes out in anger, hurls books, knocks an old man down, resists being stopped aggressively
Expresses intense frustration and impatience, hurls books, physically knocks down an elderly man, and causes a chaotic scene.
Smiles politely at Pinzon but remains silent
Gestures for Pinzon to follow him away from others and speaks cautiously
Shows awareness of timing by asking if this is a good time to meet the Queen after a major victory, demonstrating social tact and confidence in judgment.
Silently follows the procession and the crowd without showing hesitation or confusion, indicating steadiness and composure in a chaotic environment.
Falls to his knees before Queen Isabel, then speaks boldly and sincerely, engaging her with respectful challenge and insight.
Challenges the Queen directly, showing boldness but also a sense of trust and openness in dialogue.
Speaks boldly and confidently to Queen Isabel, challenging assumptions and displaying wit.
Approaches the Queen with respectful yet confident demeanor, showing social awareness and poise.
Fails to overly flatter or bow excessively, risking disfavor but maintaining sincere interaction.
Uses playful, flattering humor with Queen Isabel, calling her the only queen he knows and engaging in light banter.
Comments on Isabel's age in a way that flusters her, showing a teasing but gentle friendliness.
Demands numerous high titles and a large portion of wealth as part of his contract.
Proposes an ambitious contract demanding high noble titles, governorship, and significant shares of wealth from discovered lands.
Demands titles and wealth that others find excessive and shocking, indicating possible overestimation or arrogance.
Refuses to accept unfair contract terms, insists on fair treatment, stands up to Sanchez's condescension.
Dismisses Sanchez's proposal with a sarcastic remark, 'I'll become a monk!' showing impatience and defiance.
Pushes through crowds expressionless and distracted; shouts unexpectedly, drawing attention then continues walking as if nothing happened.
Sits alone with a glass of wine, looks at Beatrix almost sadly; shares with her that 'She said yes' without obvious joy; seems unable to share her happiness.
Beatrix places her hand gently on his mouth to comfort him; he does not reject or push her away.
Pushes his way through crowds with an expressionless and distracted demeanor, then suddenly shouts loudly attracting attention but immediately continues walking as if nothing happened.
Sits alone quietly drinking wine, appearing sad and unable to share happiness even when receiving positive news.
Calmly dispels son's fears by transforming the monster drawing into a smiling face, demonstrating imaginative reassurance and confidence.
Engages lovingly and promises his son he will take him along when the time is right, showing personal responsibility and emotional competence.
Admits to Father Marchena that he lied about the length of the journey and feels he has betrayed his family, men, and the Father, showing sincere confession and guilt.
Refuses to tell his men the full truth about the voyage length fearing they won't follow him.
Admits to a trusted figure that he lied about the journey's length, showing awareness of the truth but choosing to keep it hidden from his men.
Exhibits self-awareness about the risks and difficulties ahead and contemplates the consequences of full disclosure, indicating some level of confidence in managing the situation.
Kisses and hugs his son Fernando before departure.
Asks Fernando to be good to his mother, showing concern for family.
Clumsily hugs Diego, unable to find words.
Wordlessly hugs Santangel.
Refuses to speak to his men about doubts, fearing loss of their trust and obedience.
Seeks absolution and shows emotional vulnerability, suggesting internal conflict and lack of confident leadership in critical moments.
Gives personal encouragement to his family and supporters before departure, demonstrates awareness of social bonds and morale management.
Throws the chain with medallion to his son Diego, who catches it elated.
Shares a laugh with Santangel despite admitting uncertainty about the voyage destination.
Uses a quadrant skillfully at night to determine ship's position and confidently teaches others.
Calmly responds to doubts of crew about navigation and maintains control under uncertainty.
Does not intervene or stop Alonso’s cruel insults and bullying of the ship’s boy with a disfigured face.
Decides to follow the twenty eighth parallel until they reach land, showing navigation decision-making.
Does not provide evidence or reasoning when Alonso questions how he knows land is on the twenty eighth parallel, suggesting a possible gap in justification.
Makes precise navigational calculations using primitive methods, carefully logging data and converting it into meaningful measurements.
Demonstrates confidence and attention to detail by overseeing and verifying the ship's progress via logbook and hourglass monitoring.
Calmly acknowledges the issue with the distance sailed but insists on keeping men’s hopes alive.
Grants Captain Pinzon permission to board without conflict.
Focuses on reassuring crew despite signs of mutiny and tension.
Calmly maintains authority and tries to keep the crew's hopes alive despite signs of mutiny and difficulties.
Dismisses or downplays crew concerns by lying about distance traveled, potentially risking trust and morale.
Encourages moving forward despite adversity, tries to involve men in decision making.
Dismisses Pinzon's concerns, points out Pinzon did all the talking, comes off as confrontational.
Confronts men who disobeyed orders, stands his ground calmly.
Defends and praises the ship's boy publicly to defuse tension.
Insists on pushing forward despite opposition and dwindling resources; confidently addresses mutinous crew and confronts their doubts.
Dismisses Pinzon's concerns and previous contributions; strains collaboration with key partner.
Encourages the men to overcome their fears and offers a reward to the first man who sights land, pointing out a boy to start the watch.
Walks away abruptly to his cabin after a brief exchange with Pinzon, avoiding further interaction.
Encourages men to overcome their fears about the uncertain voyage, motivating them with confidence and a reward.
Assigns the ship's boy the important task of first lookout for land, demonstrating trust and clear delegation.
Dismisses sleep and continues to stay awake longer to keep watch, showing dedication and endurance.
Touches Mendez's shoulder and calls to him gently while he is unwell.
Reflects quietly and seems emotionally moved by the sight of land along with his crew, sharing in their joy and tears.
Raises hand as a clear signal not to fire to avoid an unnecessary conflict, showing control and confidence.
Drops his sword and walks forward alone toward potentially hostile natives, ignoring warnings from Pinzon.
Demonstrates understanding of diplomacy by putting his arm around the ship's boy, using a gesture of affection to calm the natives and ease tension.
Puts his arm around the boy, showing affection that puts the Indians at ease.
Laughs along with the Indians as they pull at his beard, sharing a moment of friendliness.
Directs his men to treat the Indians with respect and honor; forbids pillage and rape with strict punishments.
Calmly gestures affectionately towards the boy to put the Indians at ease, successfully easing tension between groups.
Addresses his men with strict orders to behave honorably, to respect the natives, and outlines punishments for pillage and rape.
Engages diplomatically with native elders and chiefs, sharing moments of mutual cultural exchange (smoking cigars, sharing wine).
Sees Alonso bitten by a snake and commands, 'Help him!'
Observes interactions closely and inquires about the meaning of 'Cuba', demonstrating curiosity and engagement.
Commands others to help Alonso after snakebite, showing leadership and quick response to emergency.
Relies on others like Utapan to interpret and lead through difficult terrain, indicating delegation but possibly limited direct action or expertise.
Turns around after noticing the group is missing to call out and wait for them, showing concern.
Observes exhausted men and jungle, and refuses to push forward despite difficulty, stating 'No. It's enough.'
Attempts to prevent the Indian shaman from forcing a milky fluid into Pinzon's mouth, but stops when Utapan intervenes; shows trust in Utapan's judgment.
Excitedly receives a gold grimacing mask from Chief Guarionex and waits patiently for a response, engaging respectfully in the gift exchange ceremony.
Attempts to prevent the Indian shaman from administering treatment to Pinzon but trusts Utapan's judgment and allows it, showing adaptive trust and cultural sensitivity.
Reacts with visible excitement at receiving the gold grimacing mask, indicating perceptiveness and recognition of valuable findings.
Waits patiently for Chief Guarionex to speak but receives silence, showing restraint and diplomatic composure in uncertain social situations.
Does not act upon the silence or attempt to break the tension actively, possibly a missed opportunity to assert leadership or clarify intentions.
Politely thanks the Chief and compliments his country, attempts to communicate positive intentions by mentioning bringing the word of God, medicine, and admiration of the people.
Fails to grasp or respond empathetically to the Chief’s question about why thousands are coming, seeming caught short and interrupting with contradictory statements.
Ends the encounter with a small smile and the words 'That's a beginning,' indicating a hopeful and somewhat friendly attitude.
Screams at sailors to get below deck to safety during violent storm
Urges Mendez to stay with him during the crisis
Writes detailed log entries reflecting on expedition progress and setbacks, showing careful observation and reflection.
Commands crew decisively during violent storm, ordering sailors to safety and maintaining presence alongside Mendez.
Fails to find expected riches or signs of civilization, which may indicate initial misjudgment in expectations or planning.
Directs men to tie him to the mast to secure himself amid the storm, showing practical leadership and quick decision-making.
Commands Mendez firmly to go below deck despite his hesitation, demonstrating assertiveness and confident command under pressure.
Counts the lightning/thunder to gauge proximity to the storm's eye, showing presence of mind and situational awareness.
Responds emotionally by screaming curses at the storm, showing human frustration but potentially a lack of control over emotions.
Reacting with amazement and staring at a mysterious object in the storm, indicating curiosity but possible distraction from immediate survival priorities.
Walks proudly down the aisle beside the king and queen, keeps eyes on Beatrix until out of vision.
Takes cigar from Moxica, demonstrates how to smoke it gently, sharing knowledge with others at the table in a friendly manner.
Describes the indigenous people in a poetic, benign way, emphasizing their natural innocence and simple lifestyle, which causes Queen Isabel to blush.
Demonstrates confident social skill by expertly handling the cigar and instructing others on how to enjoy tobacco.
Shows skill in persuasion and storytelling by vividly describing the natives and their lifestyle to Queen Isabel and others, captivating their attention.
Takes initiative by arranging a dramatic entrance of native Utapan with a casket to impress and influence the noble audience.
Presents gifts respectfully to the Queen, bows politely to guests, and shares a cordial toast with Sanchez despite their social rivalry.
Makes a sarcastic remark to Sanchez calling him a 'commoner' after a compliment.
Refuses to appoint Don Bobadilla as governor, favoring his own family members instead.
Jokes that there are no thieves and thus no need for judges, showing a light, confident demeanor.
Engages in pointed banter with Don Bobadilla, resulting in Bobadilla feeling rebuffed.
Confidently asserts that the governance positions have already been taken by his relatives, indicating control over appointments.
Attempts to downplay the need for Bobadilla's legal services by claiming there are no thieves, showing a dismissive attitude towards potential challenges.
Engages in a somewhat confrontational exchange that alienates Bobadilla and Sanchez, suggesting poor political tact or diplomacy.
Expresses need for his brothers' help despite their reluctance, shows pained surprise at their refusal.
Responds to crowd of applicants with nods, vague murmurs, and acknowledges them politely.
Puts his arms around his brothers, appeals to familial loyalty and trust.
Engages with soldiers and assistants in a friendly, humorous way, creating laughter among the crowd.
Shows affectionate and gentle behavior towards Beatrix and his son Fernando, including putting his arm around Beatrix.
Offers to arrange for his sons to serve the Queen, viewing it as a great honor, showing care and consideration for their future.
Demonstrates awareness of logistics and personnel hired for the expedition, including acknowledgment of key staff like the royal surgeon.
Shows confidence and leadership when responding promptly to the soldier's call and assessing the situation from the balcony.
Shows interpersonal competence and strategic thinking in offering to arrange for his sons to enter royal service, recognizing it as a great honor and advantage.
Uses humor and lightness (jokes about royal health) to engage and uplift those around him in a tense atmosphere.
Puts arm around Beatrix's waist, pulling her closer as they move away.
Stares with dismay at the destroyed camp and ominous signs in the jungle, showing concern.
Stands confidently beside his men and peers, ready for exploration or confrontation.
Displays dismay and uncertainty upon discovering the destruction of the camp and absence of people.
Prevents revenge massacre by forbidding retaliation and urging restraint despite his own losses.
Acknowledges shared grief openly to the men.
Calms group to prevent a bloodthirsty revenge despite pressure; reasons about being outnumbered and the necessity to stay and build rather than fight.
Fails to show decisive action against the threat or provide an immediate alternative plan besides urging restraint; relies heavily on moral appeal and warnings.
Refuses to kill the Indians despite soldiers' eagerness for blood; instructs to tell the Chief they will not harm his people and expresses desire for peace.
Calmly defuses a tense situation by refusing to retaliate despite the pressure from his soldiers, choosing diplomacy over violence.
Despite harsh accusations and provocations, maintains control and directs others on how to proceed, showing leadership and confidence.
Shouts encouragement to workers struggling in the mud to raise the watermill wheel.
Politely but firmly insists that Don Moxica use his horse to help with the work, addressing the refusal with determination rather than anger.
Thanks Don Moxica publicly after he complies and uses the horse.
Despite difficult conditions, personally supervises the work and encourages workers, showing hands-on leadership.
Insists on Don Moxica contributing his horse despite initial refusal, demonstrating determination and assertiveness.
Physically involved in effort to raise the watermill wheel, indicating willingness to engage directly in problem-solving.
Returns dirty and tired with workers, sharing their physical state
Having dinner served by an Indian woman, Nima, in the Governor's Mansion, sharing a mealtime with brothers
Encourages Giacomo to try the local food despite his discomfort and makes light jokes during dinner, creating a relaxed atmosphere among brothers.
Insists on eating iguana, pointing out that Indians eat it, showing tolerance and openness to local customs.
Jokes about being 'Governor of the Mosquitoes' after killing a mosquito by slapping his arm.
Looks down silently over the city and jungle, showing a private moment of doubt about the gold's existence.
Questions the lack of gold and admits possibility that it may not exist, showing self-doubt but awareness of situation.
Jokes about being 'Governor of the Mosquitoes,' displaying a lighthearted attitude despite adversity.
Presides over a tribunal and calmly reprimands Moxica for his brutal actions, recognizing the political and strategic consequences of Moxica's savagery.
Allows Moxica's brutal actions to occur initially without prevention, suggesting lack of control over subordinates in the field.
Tells Utapan 'We have to stop this war.'
Orders Utapan to find those responsible for the crucifixions, despite Utapan's distress.
Commands Utapan to find the perpetrators and insists on stopping the war despite being confronted with an uncomfortable truth.
Is caught short and somewhat defensive when Utapan reminds him that Spaniards harmed their God too.
Remains silent with rage but does not take immediate action in response to the crucifixion and mutilation of Spaniards.
Shouts 'Stop! Stop this!' to halt indiscriminate shooting.
Leads soldiers through dangerous jungle to pursue mutineers despite risks and losses.
Stands up shouting 'Stop! Stop this!' to halt random shooting.
Looks at the half-burnt remains of the mansion in disbelief after attack.
Leads his soldiers through the jungle at dawn searching for mutineers and carefully scans the riverbank before crossing.
Allows his men to begin crossing the river without apparent immediate tactical adaptation despite the enemy's attack causing casualties.
Gives the signal to execute the mutineer, allowing the garroting to proceed without intervention.
Stares impassively at the captured Indians packed in cages, showing no apparent emotion or empathy.
Tells Brother Buyl that his departure will not make the place more Godly, showing a blunt, unsympathetic attitude.
Treatment of Christians and heathen savages equally (as noted by Brother Buyl, apparently with a tone of astonishment).
Quietly reflects on hope and dreams with his brothers despite silence and lack of support.
Acknowledges Utapan and attempts to communicate, showing desire for connection.
Executes members of the nobility without offering tangible compensation or reconciliation.
Works alongside men to try to save the dam during the hurricane
Screams 'Let it go!' when the dam is about to break, urging men to save themselves
Subjects the natives to violence, provocation and injustice.
Orders the execution of five members of the nobility.
Congratulates Bobadilla on appointment with calm acceptance, despite being humiliated and replaced.
Responds politely to Bobadilla's mocking remarks without retaliation.
Internalizes humiliation silently, showing no open bitterness in this scene.
Laughs, embraces Diego and Fernando with joy upon their arrival, expresses happiness for Diego despite Diego feeling like an outsider.
Expresses sincere motivation to personally see and explore new lands rather than just hearing about them.
Seizes Sanchez's arm and challenges him boldly, daring him to call the guards.
Lets go of Sanchez after the confrontation without escalating the situation.
Engages Sanchez in a conversation to show pride in his achievements and to connect on a human level.
Expresses deep affection and emotional reunion with Beatrix, laughs and embraces her warmly despite their difficult circumstances.
Embraces Santangel like an old friend, sharing a moment of lightness and camaraderie during hardship.
Turns abruptly and walks away angrily after a brief exchange, showing emotional impulsiveness and withdrawal.
Turns abruptly and walks away from a triumphant exchange, showing confidence in his stance.
Acknowledges loss of material wealth but expresses emotional resilience and focus on freedom, indicating self-awareness and priorities.
Engages warmly with others despite adverse circumstances, demonstrating social skill and emotional intelligence.
No indication of planning or action to recover lost property or leverage former status visibly in this scene, potentially showing omission in pragmatic competence.
Recognizes his own limitations, admitting he is not suited to be a politician or governor, showing self-awareness.
Maintains a positive attitude despite difficulties, sharing a laugh and camaraderie with others.
Displays empathy and understanding toward his son’s seasickness without forcing him to give in.
Smiles and pats his son Fernando on the back after he vomits, showing a comforting gesture.
Watches his son discreetly, enjoying his happiness upon sighting land.
Allows the translator, an Indian, to come close and administer medicine despite initial reluctance; accepts help from a native for his illness.
Shows care and connection with his son Fernando, who anxiously watches over him and tends to him.
Stares stunned at the remains of human cannibalistic meat, shows visible shock before ordering retreat.
Urgently commands the Spaniards to leave the village immediately upon discovering danger, demonstrating quick decision-making.
Jumps to protect Fernando by attacking the charging cannibal and then comforts his son in shock by kindly offering him a flask and urging him to drink.
Jumps on an attacking enemy and repeatedly stabs him, successfully neutralizing the immediate threat.
Becomes momentarily shocked and distracted by his own fury and bloodied forearm during a dangerous escape, almost losing composure.
Keeps presence of mind to help and calm his shocked son by offering him alcohol and showing kindness despite the chaos.
Expresses deep remorse and asks his son for forgiveness, shows vulnerability and pain.
Having his son tend to his painful eyes, allowing care and support.
Dictates a letter expressing honest purpose and sincere zeal rather than self-interest.
Immediately hides dried blood on his hand and stands, showing awareness and control despite physical distress.
Insists on seeing Captain Mendez urgently, demonstrating initiative and concern for his condition.
Expresses self-reproach and emotional vulnerability ('I'll never forgive myself'), potentially showing human depth but also self-doubt.
Dictates a reasoned, clear letter to the Crown outlining his sincere purpose and findings, demonstrating skill in communication and strategic thinking.
Succumbs to fever and physical weakness, unable to act actively at the moment.
Writes a humble and emotional letter asking to be remembered with honor, appealing to charity, truth, and justice.
Listens impassively to public praise and recognition of his discovery without visible emotional response.
Writes a humble yet confident letter framing himself as a seaman who discovered a new world by Divine Will, seeking honor and remembrance.
Listens impassively to a public academic lecture that validates his discoveries and the new geography, showing calm confidence and recognition.
Shares a tender moment with Antonio de Marchena, asks if he has been forgiven, and laughs with him.
Stands quietly alone in the crowd, unnoticed and somewhat isolated.
Engages in a friendly, thoughtful conversation with Marchena, shows openness and humor.
Smiles at Beatrix and gently asks her to stay, showing a desire for companionship.
Acknowledges disagreement but maintains lightheartedness and respect during exchange with Marchena.
Expresses affection to Beatrix saying he can't keep his eyes off her and wants to catch up on missed moments.
Shows interest and concern about Diego and Dona Maria's wellbeing.
Smiles and engages warmly with Fernando about letters and friends.
Expresses a clear, confident vision of wanting to 'travel all over the seas' and 'get behind the weather' as told to his son.
Demonstrates care and attentiveness towards his son by watching him with amusement and interacting warmly.
No direct display of concrete skill, decision-making, or problem-solving in this excerpt; mostly personal and familial moments.
Encourages Diego to show affection to his brother, Fernando.
Expresses care about Diego's education and well-being by selecting a good teacher and deciding what is best for him.
Successfully obtains a letter granting him a hearing at the University of Salamanca, demonstrating initiative and networking.
Reacts with visible excitement and disbelief at getting the letter, showing eagerness and confidence in his mission.
Explains his planned route to Asia with clarity, referencing maps and known routes, showing knowledge and preparedness.
Shows personal warmth and affection towards Beatrix, attempts to maintain family bonds despite absences.
Mentally distracted and emotional, evident in pouring wine into child's water to distract him, showing interpersonal skill and attentiveness.
Acknowledges likelihood of long absence and impact on personal relationships, showing awareness of personal consequences but no apparent plan to mitigate them.
Observed watching university students but not explicitly engaging or acting in the scene, indicating passivity or contemplation.
Pins up new maps carefully, showing attention to detail and preparation.
Behaves cautiously by moving away from others to speak privately with Pinzon, indicating strategic discretion.
Responds minimally to Pinzon's questions and smiles without engaging fully, which could suggest reserved confidence or lack of openness.
Nods in agreement with Pinzon, shows openness to collaboration.
Laughs openly with Pinzon, displaying friendly rapport.
Crosses himself and looks for approval before speaking, indicating a sincere and respectful demeanor.
Nods in agreement quickly and cooperates with Pinzon's plan to seek help.
Laughs and hides behind a map, showing a moment of informal levity but also possibly insecurity.
Shows interest and asks where he can meet the court financier, taking a proactive step toward gaining support.
Crosses himself before speaking, signaling possible hesitation or discomfort, but still proceeds.
Engages confidently and wittily with Queen Isabel, showing social ease and composure in a high-stakes situation.
Attempts light humor and personal remarks that slightly unsettle Isabel, demonstrating his confidence and social intelligence.
Does not directly address the Queen's decision or aggressively advocate for his proposal, showing restraint or possible missed opportunity to press his case.
Confidently refuses to accept unfair contract terms, standing firm on his demands despite pressure.
Engages in verbal sparring displaying ambition and self-assurance, showing sharp awareness of political dynamics.
Dismisses the offered contract quickly and decisively after reading it, indicating quick assessment skills.
Explains the use of the quadrant patiently to Mendez and encourages him despite his nervousness.
Speaks softly saying 'may God be with us' showing care and hope for the men.
Commands Mendez brusquely to 'Speak!' when sensing hesitation.
Stands silently on the poop deck, scrutinizing the horizon while sailors laugh and disregard the boy's distress.
Reflexively reacts to a mosquito biting him, then slowly gets to his feet, showing alertness and physical responsiveness even when tired.
Stares intently into darkness and dawn, desperate to see land; his focus and determination indicate persistence and confidence in his goal.
Kneels by the injured Mendez, showing empathy and leadership by checking on his crew.
Initially cannot see the land himself, relying on others to identify it, which may indicate some limitation in perception or patience.
Watches the land appear in disbelief with mouth open and tears in eyes, which suggests emotional overwhelm and perhaps a momentary loss of composure.
Becomes visibly moved and tearful when witnessing the new land, showing sincere emotional response.
Attempts to speak with awe and respect, acknowledging divine grace and royal authority.
Claims the island formally in the name of monarchs, leading his men confidently but without overt friendliness or warmth toward them.
Leads the landing party confidently, claiming the island formally by signing the contract and proclaiming possession with authority.
Is momentarily overwhelmed and emotional, struggling to find words at the moment of claiming the land, needing external help to continue.
Insists that Pinzon give the dagger to the Indian, despite Pinzon's hesitation.
Insists on giving his dagger to the Indian despite Pinzon's objection.
Writes thoughtful, visionary entries in his journal reflecting on the discovery.
Draws Utapan's face with care and shows it to him, sharing a moment of mutual laughter and puts a hand on his shoulder in a gesture of friendship.
Follows Utapan through the jungle attentively and obeys his command to sit, showing respect and trust.
Doggedly keeps up with UTAPAN despite harsh conditions.
Calls out to UTAPAN and waits for him obediently to return, showing leadership and control.
Confronted with exhausted, feverish men and harsh terrain, decides to end the expedition declaring 'No. It's enough.'
Attempts to communicate through a translator with the Chief, expressing gratitude and intentions clearly.
Fails to understand the Chief's simple question about why Columbus plans to leave thousands of men.
Persists in communicating motives despite language barriers, showing some confidence and composure.
Commands Mendez to stay with him and helps tie himself to the mast to make a critical decision during the storm.
Screams at Mendez to go below deck despite Mendez's hesitation, showing urgency and impatience.
Walks proudly in a grand procession, recognized and honored by nobles, royalty, and dignitaries.
Maintains composure and confidence during public ceremonies, demonstrating assuredness in his achievements.
Keeps personal focus (on Beatrix) amid grand public attention, hinting at emotional distraction or divided attention.
Encourages his brother to try unfamiliar local food to adapt, showing practical acceptance and cultural flexibility.
Dismisses his brother's concerns somewhat brusquely, potentially underestimating cultural or personal limits.
Maintains faith and patience in the face of no immediate gold profits, encouraging giving more time for results.
Fails to ensure the health and safety of his crew, resulting in widespread disease and death among the men.
Condemns Moxica's brutality and expresses concern for resulting chaos and tribal unity against them.
Presides over tribunal ensuring punishment for Moxica's cruelty.
Kills a mutineer attacking him during battle.
Leads his men courageously through deadly combat despite danger.
Shows no mercy or hesitation in violent confrontation.
Responds quietly and thoughtfully about the situation, acknowledges a harsh reality distinct from his dreams.
Sits alone all night reflecting on his failures and the gap between expectation and reality.
Attempts to communicate with Utapan, showing willingness to engage but fails due to language/cultural barriers.
Fails to find gold despite promises; subjects natives to violence and injustice; orders execution of nobles.
Despite being imprisoned and in poor physical condition, remains focused on his exploration goals, showing determination and intellect by referring to maps and his plan to explore the mainland.

Expresses an urgent desire to return to exploration despite his very weak and feverish state, which his son Diego calls madness, indicating a possible lack of practical judgment regarding his health and situation.
Drops to his knees before Queen Isabel as a sign of respect and humility.
Meets Isabel's eyes clearly despite physical deterioration, showing sincerity and steadiness.
Interrupts Isabel while she speaks, but is stopped by her gesture.
Listens attentively to the Old Indian's drawings and explanations, showing interest and respect.
Engages the Indian translator politely and looks to communicate clearly about geography.
Despite initial puzzlement, reacts with growing excitement and shares the moment with his son.
Reacts with shock and horror upon discovering remains of human beings, urgently commands the soldiers to retreat from the dangerous village.
Appears unnoticed and distant among students in a crowd, suggesting diminished presence or influence.
Shares a quiet, reflective moment with Antonio de Marchena, showing personal humility and the ability to maintain meaningful relationships despite past conflicts.
Insists on discovering things for himself despite risks and hardships to self and others.
